Futurism</div><div class="block px-3 mt-5 lg:flex lg:px-0"><section id="incArticle" class="post-content w-full space-y-4 lg:w-2/3 font-b text-3"><p>Few companies in the history of capitalism have amassed as much wealth and influence as Meta.</p><p>A global superpower in the information space, Meta — the parent company of Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, and Threads — has a market cap of $1.68 trillion at the time of writing, which for a rough sense of scale is more than the <a href="https://www.worldometers.info/gdp/gdp-by-country/" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">gross domestic product of Spain</a>.<b> </b></p><p>In spite of its immense influence, none of its internal algorithms can be scrutinized by public watchdogs. Its host country, the United States, has largely <a href="https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/26317877221129290" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">turned a blind eye</a> to its dealings in exchange for free use of Meta's vast <a href="https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=5113445" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">surveillance capabilities</a>.</p><p>That lack of oversight coupled with Meta's near-omnipresence as a social utility has had devastating consequences throughout the world, manifesting in crises like the <a href="https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/14623528.2024.2375122" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">genocide of Muslims</a> in Myanmar, or the <a href="https://www.hrw.org/report/2023/12/21/metas-broken-promises/systemic-censorship-palestine-content-instagram-and" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">systemic suppression</a> of Palestinian rights organizations.</p><p>How do you uncover the harms caused by one of the most powerful companies on earth? In the case of public violence, the evidence <a href="https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2022/09/myanmar-facebooks-systems-promoted-violence-against-rohingya-meta-owes-reparations-new-report/" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">isn't hard to trace</a>. However, Meta's unprecedented corporate dynasty also creates less obvious harms, which scores of scholars, researchers, and journalists are devoting entire careers to uncovering.</p><p>One prominent group of said investigators is GLAAD, the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, which recently released its <a href="https://glaad.org/smsi/social-media-safety-index-2025/" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">annual report</a> on social media safety, privacy, and expression for LGBTQ people.</p><p>The report notes that Meta has undergone a "particularly extreme" <a href="https://futurism.com/meta-lgbtq-hate-speech" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">ideological shift</a> over the past year, adding harmful exceptions to its content moderation policies while disproportionately suppressing LGBTQ users and their content. The tech giant has also failed to give LGBTQ users sovereignty over their own <a href="https://www.privacyguides.org/articles/2025/06/03/importance-of-privacy-for-the-queer-community/#public-photos-during-events" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">personal data</a>, which it collects, analyzes, and wields to generate huge profits.</p><p>While Meta collects all of our data — from which it draws over <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/dereksaul/2023/10/25/meta-earnings-record-profits-sales-as-ads-stay-robust-during-zuckerbergs-year-of-efficiency/" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">95 percent</a> of its revenue — the practice is particularly harmful to LGBTQ users, who then have to contend with <a href="https://kdd.org/exploration_files/4_specialsectionBIAS_5.pdf" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">algorithmic biases</a>, <a href="https://www.dailydot.com/irl/facebook-ads-lgbtq/" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">non-consensual outing</a>, <a href="https://www.emerald.com/insight/content/doi/10.1108/s1521-613620220000027012/full/html" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">harassment</a>, and in some countries <a href="https://www.wired.com/story/tunisia-police-facebook/" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">state oppression</a>.</p><p>"It's a dangerous time, certainly for trans people, who as a minority have been so ridiculously maligned, but also a dangerous time for gay people, openly bi[sexual] people, people who are different in any way," says Sarah Roberts, a UCLA professor and Director of the Center for Critical Internet Inquiry.</p><p>To address these shortcomings and the dangers they introduce, GLAAD made a number of recommendations. One key suggestion was to improve moderation "by providing training for all content moderators focused on LGBTQ safety, privacy and expression." The media advocacy group doesn't mince words, adding that "AI systems should be used to flag for human review, not for automated removals."</p><p>However, it doesn't look like Meta got the message.</p><p>Weeks after GLAAD issued its findings, <a href="https://www.npr.org/2025/05/31/nx-s1-5407870/meta-ai-facebook-instagram-risks" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">internal Meta documents leaked to <em>NPR</em></a> revealed the company's plan to hand 90 percent of its privacy and integrity reviews over to "artificial intelligence."</p><p>This will impact nearly every new feature introduced to its platforms, where human moderators would typically evaluate new features for risks to privacy and safety, and the wellbeing of user groups like minors, immigrants, and LGBTQ people.</p><p>Meta's internal risk assessment is an already opaque process, and Roberts notes that government attempts at risk oversight, like the EU's Digital Services Act, are likewise a labyrinth of filings which are largely dictated by the social media companies themselves. AI, chock full of biases and prone to errors — as admitted by <a href="https://thenextweb.com/news/meta-yann-lecun-ai-behind-human-intelligence" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">Meta's own AI chief</a> — is certain to make the situation even worse.</p><p>Earlier this week, meanwhile, the <a href="https://www.wsj.com/tech/ai/meta-aims-to-fully-automate-ad-creation-using-ai-7d82e249" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue"><em>Wall Street Journal </em>revealed</a> Meta's plans to fully automate advertising via the company's generative AI software, which will allow advertisers to "fully create and target ads" directly, with no human in the loop.</p><p>This includes hyper-personalized ads, writes the <em>WSJ</em>, "so that users see different versions of the same ad in real time, based on factors such as geolocation."</p><p>Data hoarders like Meta — which <a href="https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2025/01/mad-meta-dont-let-them-collect-and-monetize-your-personal-data" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">track you</a> even when you're not using its platforms — have long been able to profile LGBTQ users based on gender identify and sexual orientation, including those who aren't publicly out.</p><p>Removing any human from these already sinister practices serves to streamline operations and <a href="https://www.techpolicy.press/musk-ai-and-the-weaponization-of-administrative-error/" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">distance Meta</a> from its own actions — "<em>we </em>didn't out gay users living under an oppressive government," the company can say, "even if our AI did." It's no coincidence that Meta had already disbanded its "<a href="https://www.theverge.com/2023/11/18/23966980/meta-disbanded-responsible-ai-team-artificial-intelligence" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">Responsible AI</a>" team as early as 2023.</p><p>At the root of these decisions — Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg's <a href="https://jacobin.com/2025/01/mark-zuckerberg-meta-trump-tech" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">right wing turn</a> notwithstanding — is the calculated drive to maximize revenue.</p><p>"If there's no reason to rigorously moderate harmful content, then why pay so many content moderators? Why engage researchers to look into the circulation of this kind of content?" observes Roberts. "There ends up being a real cost savings there."</p><p>"One of the things I've always said is that content moderation of social media is not primarily about protecting people, it's about brand management," she told <em>Futurism</em>. "It's about the platform managing its brand in order to make the most hospitable environment for advertisers."</p><p>Sometimes these <a href="https://www.techpolicy.press/free-speech-was-never-the-goal-of-tech-billionaires-power-was/" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">corporate priorities</a> line up with progressive causes, like LGBTQ user safety or voter registration. But when they don't, Roberts notes, "dollars are dollars."</p><p>"We are looking at multibillion-dollar companies, the most capitalized companies in the world, who have operated with impunity for many, many years," she said. "How do you convince them that they should care, when other powerful sectors are telling them the opposite?"</p><p class=""><strong>More on Meta: </strong><a However, Meta's unprecedented corporate dynasty also creates less obvious harms, which scores of scholars, researchers, and journalists are devoting entire careers to uncovering.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne prominent group of said investigators is GLAAD, the Gay \u0026amp; Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, which recently released its \u003ca href=\"https://glaad.org/smsi/social-media-safety-index-2025/\"\u003eannual report\u003c/a\u003e on social media safety, privacy, and expression for LGBTQ people.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe report notes that Meta has undergone a \"particularly extreme\" \u003ca href=\"https://futurism.com/meta-lgbtq-hate-speech\"\u003eideological shift\u003c/a\u003e over the past year, adding harmful exceptions to its content moderation policies while disproportionately suppressing LGBTQ users and their content. in the information space, Meta — the parent company of Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, and Threads — has a market cap of $1.68 trillion at the time of writing, which for a rough sense of scale is more than the \u003ca href=\"https://www.worldometers.info/gdp/gdp-by-country/\"\u003egross domestic product of Spain\u003c/a\u003e.\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn spite of its immense influence, none of its internal algorithms can be scrutinized by public watchdogs. Its host country, the United States, has largely \u003ca href=\"https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/26317877221129290\"\u003eturned a blind eye\u003c/a\u003e to its dealings in exchange for free use of Meta's vast \u003ca href=\"https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=5113445\"\u003esurveillance capabilities\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat lack of oversight coupled with Meta's near-omnipresence as a social utility has had devastating consequences throughout the world, manifesting in crises like the \u003ca href=\"https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/14623528.2024.2375122\"\u003egenocide of Muslims\u003c/a\u003e in Myanmar, or the \u003ca href=\"https://www.hrw.org/report/2023/12/21/metas-broken-promises/systemic-censorship-palestine-content-instagram-and\"\u003esystemic suppression\u003c/a\u003e of Palestinian rights organizations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHow do you uncover the harms caused by one of the most powerful companies on earth? In the case of public violence, the evidence \u003ca href=\"https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2022/09/myanmar-facebooks-systems-promoted-violence-against-rohingya-meta-owes-reparations-new-report/\"\u003eisn't hard to trace\u003c/a\u003e. However, Meta's unprecedented corporate dynasty also creates less obvious harms, which scores of scholars, researchers, and journalists are devoting entire careers to uncovering.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne prominent group of said investigators is GLAAD, the Gay \u0026amp; Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, which recently released its \u003ca href=\"https://glaad.org/smsi/social-media-safety-index-2025/\"\u003eannual report\u003c/a\u003e on social media safety, privacy, and expression for LGBTQ people.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe report notes that Meta has undergone a \"particularly extreme\" \u003ca href=\"https://futurism.com/meta-lgbtq-hate-speech\"\u003eideological shift\u003c/a\u003e over the past year, adding harmful exceptions to its content moderation policies while disproportionately suppressing LGBTQ users and their content. The tech giant has also failed to give LGBTQ users sovereignty over their own \u003ca href=\"https://www.privacyguides.org/articles/2025/06/03/importance-of-privacy-for-the-queer-community/#public-photos-during-events\"\u003epersonal data\u003c/a\u003e, which it collects, analyzes, and wields to generate huge profits.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile Meta collects all of our data — from which it draws over \u003ca href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/dereksaul/2023/10/25/meta-earnings-record-profits-sales-as-ads-stay-robust-during-zuckerbergs-year-of-efficiency/\"\u003e95 percent\u003c/a\u003e of its revenue — the practice is particularly harmful to LGBTQ users, who then have to contend with \u003ca href=\"https://kdd.org/exploration_files/4_specialsectionBIAS_5.pdf\"\u003ealgorithmic biases\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://www.dailydot.com/irl/facebook-ads-lgbtq/\"\u003enon-consensual outing\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://www.emerald.com/insight/content/doi/10.1108/s1521-613620220000027012/full/html\"\u003eharassment\u003c/a\u003e, and in some countries \u003ca href=\"https://www.wired.com/story/tunisia-police-facebook/\"\u003estate oppression\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\"It's a dangerous time, certainly for trans people, who as a minority have been so ridiculously maligned, but also a dangerous time for gay people, openly bi[sexual] people, people who are different in any way,\" says Sarah Roberts, a UCLA professor and Director of the Center for Critical Internet Inquiry.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo address these shortcomings and the dangers they introduce, GLAAD made a number of recommendations. One key suggestion was to improve moderation \"by providing training for all content moderators focused on LGBTQ safety, privacy and expression.\" The media advocacy group doesn't mince words, adding that \"AI systems should be used to flag for human review, not for automated removals.\"\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, it doesn't look like Meta got the message.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWeeks after GLAAD issued its findings, \u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/2025/05/31/nx-s1-5407870/meta-ai-facebook-instagram-risks\"\u003einternal Meta documents leaked to \u003cem\u003eNPR\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e revealed the company's plan to hand 90 percent of its privacy and integrity reviews over to \"artificial intelligence.\"\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis will impact nearly every new feature introduced to its platforms, where human moderators would typically evaluate new features for risks to privacy and safety, and the wellbeing of user groups like minors, immigrants, and LGBTQ people.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMeta's internal risk assessment is an already opaque process, and Roberts notes that government attempts at risk oversight, like the EU's Digital Services Act, are likewise a labyrinth of filings which are largely dictated by the social media companies themselves. AI, chock full of biases and prone to errors — as admitted by \u003ca href=\"https://thenextweb.com/news/meta-yann-lecun-ai-behind-human-intelligence\"\u003eMeta's own AI chief\u003c/a\u003e — is certain to make the situation even worse.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEarlier this week, meanwhile, the \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/tech/ai/meta-aims-to-fully-automate-ad-creation-using-ai-7d82e249\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eWall Street Journal \u003c/em\u003erevealed\u003c/a\u003e Meta's plans to fully automate advertising via the company's generative AI software, which will allow advertisers to \"fully create and target ads\" directly, with no human in the loop.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis includes hyper-personalized ads, writes the \u003cem\u003eWSJ\u003c/em\u003e, \"so that users see different versions of the same ad in real time, based on factors such as geolocation.\"\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eData hoarders like Meta — which \u003ca href=\"https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2025/01/mad-meta-dont-let-them-collect-and-monetize-your-personal-data\"\u003etrack you\u003c/a\u003e even when you're not using its platforms — have long been able to profile LGBTQ users based on gender identify and sexual orientation, including those who aren't publicly out.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRemoving any human from these already sinister practices serves to streamline operations and \u003ca href=\"https://www.techpolicy.press/musk-ai-and-the-weaponization-of-administrative-error/\"\u003edistance Meta\u003c/a\u003e from its own actions — \"\u003cem\u003ewe \u003c/em\u003edidn't out gay users living under an oppressive government,\" the company can say, \"even if our AI did.\" It's no coincidence that Meta had already disbanded its \"\u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2023/11/18/23966980/meta-disbanded-responsible-ai-team-artificial-intelligence\"\u003eResponsible AI\u003c/a\u003e\" team as early as 2023.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt the root of these decisions — Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg's \u003ca href=\"https://jacobin.com/2025/01/mark-zuckerberg-meta-trump-tech\"\u003eright wing turn\u003c/a\u003e notwithstanding — is the calculated drive to maximize revenue.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\"If there's no reason to rigorously moderate harmful content, then why pay so many content moderators? Why engage researchers to look into the circulation of this kind of content?\" observes Roberts. \"There ends up being a real cost savings there.\"\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\"One of the things I've always said is that content moderation of social media is not primarily about protecting people, it's about brand management,\" she told \u003cem\u003eFuturism\u003c/em\u003e. \"It's about the platform managing its brand in order to make the most hospitable environment for advertisers.\"\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSometimes these \u003ca href=\"https://www.techpolicy.press/free-speech-was-never-the-goal-of-tech-billionaires-power-was/\"\u003ecorporate priorities\u003c/a\u003e line up with progressive causes, like LGBTQ user safety or voter registration. But when they don't, Roberts notes, \"dollars are dollars.\"\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\"We are looking at multibillion-dollar companies, the most capitalized companies in the world, who have operated with impunity for many, many years,\" she said. \"How do you convince them that they should care, when other powerful sectors are telling them the Few companies in the history of capitalism have amassed as much wealth and influence as Meta.

A global superpower in the information space, Meta — the parent company of Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, and Threads — has a market cap of $1.68 trillion at the time of writing, which for a rough sense of scale is more than the gross domestic product of Spain.

In spite of its immense influence, none of its internal algorithms can be scrutinized by public watchdogs. Its host country, the United States, has largely turned a blind eye to its dealings in exchange for free use of Meta's vast surveillance capabilities.

That lack of oversight coupled with Meta's near-omnipresence as a social utility has had devastating consequences throughout the world, manifesting in crises like the genocide of Muslims in Myanmar, or the systemic suppression of Palestinian rights organizations.

How do you uncover the harms caused by one of the most powerful companies on earth? In the case of public violence, the evidence isn't hard to trace. However, Meta's unprecedented corporate dynasty also creates less obvious harms, which scores of scholars, researchers, and journalists are devoting entire careers to uncovering.

One prominent group of said investigators is GLAAD, the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, which recently released its annual report on social media safety, privacy, and expression for LGBTQ people.

The report notes that Meta has undergone a "particularly extreme" ideological shift over the past year, adding harmful exceptions to its content moderation policies while disproportionately suppressing LGBTQ users and their content. The tech giant has also failed to give LGBTQ users sovereignty over their own personal data, which it collects, analyzes, and wields to generate huge profits.

While Meta collects all of our data — from which it draws over 95 percent of its revenue — the practice is particularly harmful to LGBTQ users, who then have to contend with algorithmic biases, non-consensual outing, harassment, and in some countries state oppression.

"It's a dangerous time, certainly for trans people, who as a minority have been so ridiculously maligned, but also a dangerous time for gay people, openly bi[sexual] people, people who are different in any way," says Sarah Roberts, a UCLA professor and Director of the Center for Critical Internet Inquiry.

To address these shortcomings and the dangers they introduce, GLAAD made a number of recommendations. One key suggestion was to improve moderation "by providing training for all content moderators focused on LGBTQ safety, privacy and expression." The media advocacy group doesn't mince words, adding that "AI systems should be used to flag for human review, not for automated removals."

However, it doesn't look like Meta got the message.

Weeks after GLAAD issued its findings, internal Meta documents leaked to NPR revealed the company's plan to hand 90 percent of its privacy and integrity reviews over to "artificial intelligence."

This will impact nearly every new feature introduced to its platforms, where human moderators would typically evaluate new features for risks to privacy and safety, and the wellbeing of user groups like minors, immigrants, and LGBTQ people.

Meta's internal risk assessment is an already opaque process, and Roberts notes that government attempts at risk oversight, like the EU's Digital Services Act, are likewise a labyrinth of filings which are largely dictated by the social media companies themselves. AI, chock full of biases and prone to errors — as admitted by Meta's own AI chief — is certain to make the situation even worse.

Earlier this week, meanwhile, the Wall Street Journal revealed Meta's plans to fully automate advertising via the company's generative AI software, which will allow advertisers to "fully create and target ads" directly, with no human in the loop.

This includes hyper-personalized ads, writes the WSJ, "so that users see different versions of the same ad in real time, based on factors such as geolocation."

Data hoarders like Meta — which track you even when you're not using its platforms — have long been able to profile LGBTQ users based on gender identify and sexual orientation, including those who aren't publicly out.

Removing any human from these already sinister practices serves to streamline operations and distance Meta from its own actions — "we didn't out gay users living under an oppressive government," the company can say, "even if our AI did." It's no coincidence that Meta had already disbanded its "Responsible AI" team as early as 2023.

At the root of these decisions — Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg's right wing turn notwithstanding — is the calculated drive to maximize revenue.

"If there's no reason to rigorously moderate harmful content, then why pay so many content moderators? Why engage researchers to look into the circulation of this kind of content?" observes Roberts. "There ends up being a real cost savings there."

"One of the things I've always said is that content moderation of social media is not primarily about protecting people, it's about brand management," she told Futurism. "It's about the platform managing its brand in order to make the most hospitable environment for advertisers."

Sometimes these corporate priorities line up with progressive causes, like LGBTQ user safety or voter registration. But when they don't, Roberts notes, "dollars are dollars."

"We are looking at multibillion-dollar companies, the most capitalized companies in the world, who have operated with impunity for many, many years," she said. "How do you convince them that they should care, when other powerful sectors are telling them the opposite?"
